- First Microfinance Policy Framework introduced December 15, 2005
- Revised in 2011
- Latest version: **Guidelines for the Regulation and Supervision of Microfinance Banks in Nigeria, January 2020**

**Regulatory Framework:**
- Governed by Banks and Other Financial Institutions Act (BOFIA) 2020, Sections 61-63
- CBN Act 7 of 2007, Section 33(1)(b)

**MFB Categories and Capital Requirements:**

| Category | Minimum Capital | Operating Scope |
|----------|----------------|----------------|
| **Tier 1 Unit MFB** | ₦200,000,000 | Single LGA |
| **Tier 2 Unit MFB** | ₦200,000,000 | Single LGA (enhanced) |
| **State MFB** | ₦1,000,000,000 | One State or FCT |
| **National MFB** | ₦5,000,000,000 | Multiple States |

**Operational Scope Details:**
- **State MFB:** Authorized in one State or FCT, max 2 branches per LGA unless branch/cash center in every LGA
- **National MFB:** Authorized in multiple States including FCT, max 10 branches at launch

**Licensing Process - 3 Stages:**
1. Pre-licensing presentation to CBN on business case
2. Formal license application
3. Post-approval compliance verification

**Ownership Rules:**
- No individual/group/corporate entity shall own controlling interest in more than one MFB (except with CBN approval)
- Can be established by: individuals, groups, community development associations, private corporate entities, foreign investors

### 3.2 CBN DIGITAL FINANCIAL SERVICES GUIDELINES

**SOURCE_URL:** https://www.cbn.gov.ng/Out/2024/RSD/Digital Financial Services and Financial Inclusion in Nigeia, Milestones and New Direction.pdf
**RETRIEVED:** 2025-12-03
**COUNTRY:** Nigeria
**CATEGORY:** Regulatory
**DOCUMENT_TYPE:** Policy Guidelines
**CERTAINTY:** High
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT:** 2024
**CONTENT:**

**Major 2024 Regulations:**

**1. CBN Guidelines on International Money Transfer Services 2024** (January 2024)
- Aim: Liberalize foreign exchange market
- Promote diaspora remittances and foreign capital inflows
- **Critical Change:** Prevents fintech startups from carrying out IMTO services
- Application fees increased to **NGN 10 million**
- Minimum operating capital: **USD 1 million** for foreign IMTOs, naira equivalent for indigenous operators

**2. CBN Risk-Based Cybersecurity Framework 2024** (May 2024)
- Replaces October 2018 framework
- Addresses emerging gaps in cybersecurity landscape
- Considers requirements of BOFIA 2020 and NDPA 2023

**3. Pan-African Payment and Settlement System (PAPSS) Guidelines** (March 2024)
- Cross-border financial market infrastructure
- Enables payment transactions across Africa
- Allows individuals and banks to initiate transactions for trade and payment services

**Existing Guidelines:**
- Operations of Bank Accounts for Virtual Assets Service Providers (2023)
- Operational Guidelines for Open Banking in Nigeria (2023)
- Customer Due Diligence Regulations (2023)
- Guidelines on Contactless Payments in Nigeria (2023)

**Enforcement Actions 2024:**
- Over NGN 15 billion in penalties imposed on banks (Oct-Dec 2024)
- About NGN 1.5 billion penalties in first six months of 2024
- Violations: Foreign exchange guidelines and other regulatory offenses

**Regulatory Sentiment:** Landscape becoming more friendly and encouraging rather than prohibitive/restrictive

### 3.3 CBN AGENT BANKING GUIDELINES 2025

**SOURCE_URL:** https://www.cbn.gov.ng/Out/2025/CCD/CIRCULAR AND GUIDELINES FOR THE OPERATIONS OF AGENT BANKING IN NIGERIA OCTOBER 6 2025.pdf
**RETRIEVED:** 2025-12-03
**COUNTRY:** Nigeria
**CATEGORY:** Regulatory
**DOCUMENT_TYPE:** Guidelines
**CERTAINTY:** High
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT:** 2025-10-06
**CONTENT:**

**Latest Updates - October 6, 2025:**
Most comprehensive regulatory overhaul since agent banking began in 2013.

**Transaction Limits:**
- Daily cash-out limit per agent: **₦1.2 million**
- Individual customers - daily: **₦100,000**
- Individual customers - weekly: **₦500,000** (deposits and withdrawals)
- Bill payments - daily: **₦100,000**
- Bill payments - weekly: **₦100,000**
- All transactions must be conducted in real-time through secure, interoperable systems

**Agent Exclusivity (Effective April 1, 2026):**
- POS agents must be exclusive to one principal
- Applies to: banks, mobile money operators, microfinance banks, payment service banks

**Super Agents Requirements:**
- Must have **minimum 50+ agents** spread across Nigeria's 6 geopolitical zones
- Ensures broader coverage and access in underserved areas

**Geo-fencing Requirements:**
- Any device deployed to agent must be geo-fenced/tagged
- Must operate within agreed registered premises/location

**Record Keeping & Reporting:**
- Agents must issue receipts with names and location coordinates
- Transaction records preserved for **minimum 5 years**
- Financial institutions submit monthly returns by 10th of every month:
  - Transaction volumes and values
  - Incidents of fraud
  - Number of active agents
  - Customer complaints
  - Agent training details

**Relocation Rules:**
- No agent can relocate, transfer, or close premises without prior written approval from principal/super agent

**Enforcement:**
- Suspension of agent onboarding
- Removal of management officials
- Revocation of licenses

**December 2024 Cash-Out Limits Circular:**
- Weekly cash withdrawal limit per customer: **₦500,000**
- Part of CBN's cash-less economy advancement

### 3.4 CBN CONSUMER PROTECTION FRAMEWORK

**SOURCE_URL:** https://www.cbn.gov.ng/out/2016/cfpd/consumer protection framework (final).pdf
**RETRIEVED:** 2025-12-03
**COUNTRY:** Nigeria
**CATEGORY:** Regulatory
**DOCUMENT_TYPE:** Framework
**CERTAINTY:** High
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT:** 2016 (Framework) / 2019 (Regulations)
**CONTENT:**

**CBN Consumer Protection Framework 2016:**

**Institutional Background:**
- Consumer Protection Unit created 2010
- Achieved department status in April 2012
- Purpose: 1) Resolve consumer complaints against financial institutions, 2) Entrench fair and responsible conduct

**Broad Objective:**
Enhance consumer confidence in financial services industry and promote financial stability, growth and innovation.

**9 Key Consumer Protection Principles:**
Framework contains high-level provisions supporting nine key principles (specific principles listed in full document).

**Scope of Application:**
All CBN-regulated financial institutions:
- Commercial or Merchant Banks
- Specialized Banks
- Microfinance Banks (MFBs)
- Discount Houses (DH)
- Development Finance Institutions (DFIs)
- Finance Houses (FHs)
- Bureaux-de-Change (BDCs)
- Primary Mortgage Banks
- Other CBN-licensed institutions

**Consumer Protection Regulations 2019:**
- Gives effect to principles in Framework
- Financial institutions (including Fintechs) must develop policy documenting processes, procedures, and systems for compliance

**Complaint Resolution:**
- First escalate to institution
- If dissatisfied, escalate to: Director, Consumer Protection Department, CBN, Abuja
- Email: cpd@cbn.gov.ng

**Sanctions for Non-Compliance:**
a) Refund to customers
b) Letter of apology
c) Restriction on activities
d) Suspension from inter-bank activities
e) Suspension/withdrawal of foreign exchange dealership license
f) Denial of approvals
g) Publication of infractions and sanctions
h) Monetary penalties
i) Product recall
j) Revocation of banking license

**Consumer Rights:**
- Engage with preferred financial institutions
- Terminate contracts
- Change/switch FIs, products/services (subject to contractual terms)

### 3.5 CBN CYBERSECURITY FRAMEWORK 2024

**SOURCE_URL:** https://www.cbn.gov.ng/Out/2024/BSD/CBN Risk-Based Cybersecurity Framework for DMBs and PSBs_2024.pdf
**RETRIEVED:** 2025-12-03
**COUNTRY:** Nigeria
**CATEGORY:** Regulatory
**DOCUMENT_TYPE:** Framework
**CERTAINTY:** High
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT:** 2024
**CONTENT:**

**CBN Risk-Based Cybersecurity Framework and Guidelines for DMBs and PSBs 2024:**

**Scope and Applicability:**
Applies to Supervised Financial Institutions (SFIs):
- Commercial banks
- Merchant banks
- Non-Interest banks
- Payment Service banks

**Framework Structure - 7 Parts:**
1. Cybersecurity Governance and Oversight
2. Cybersecurity Risk Management System
3. Enhancing Cybersecurity Resilience
4. Emerging Technologies
5. Metrics, Monitoring & Reporting
6. Compliance with Statutory requirements (BOFIA 2020, NDPA 2023)
7. Enforcement

**Governance Requirements:**
- CISO (Chief Information Security Officer) responsible for overseeing and implementing cybersecurity program
- Cybersecurity committee required
- Executive level priority

**Compliance and Reporting:**
- SFIs must obtain CBN approval before deploying emerging technologies and products
- Comply with applicable statutes and regulations
- **Cyber incidents must be reported to CBN within 24 hours**

**Enforcement:**
- Annual cybersecurity supervisory review and evaluation exercises
- Risk-based examinations
- Annual industry compliance audits
- Periodic spot checks
- Sanctions under BOFIA 2020 for non-compliance

**IT Standards Blueprint:**
Nigeria Financial Services Industry Information Technology Standards Blueprint (2019) provides framework for:
- Cloud services usage
- Risk management
- Security procedures

**Statutory Compliance Requirements:**
Must comply with:
- Cybercrimes Act 2015
- NDPA 2023
- National Cybersecurity Policy
- CBN directives

**Mandatory Participation:**
- Industry cyber exercises (drills/war games)
- NigFinCERT or similar bodies
- Assess preparedness for cyber incidents

### 3.6 CBN AML/CFT REGULATIONS

**SOURCE_URL:** https://www.cbn.gov.ng/supervision/AML-CFT/
**RETRIEVED:** 2025-12-03
**COUNTRY:** Nigeria
**CATEGORY:** Regulatory
**DOCUMENT_TYPE:** Regulations
**CERTAINTY:** High
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT:** 2024
**CONTENT:**

**Key Regulatory Bodies:**
- **Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN)** - Formulates and implements AML/CFT regulations for banks and financial institutions
- **Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC)** - Investigates and prosecutes money laundering and financial crimes
- **Nigerian Financial Intelligence Unit (NFIU)** - Receives, analyzes, and disseminates suspicious transaction reports

**Primary AML/CFT Laws:**
- Money Laundering Act
- Terrorism Prevention Act 2012 (as amended)
- Terrorism Prevention (Freezing of International Terrorist Funds) Regulations 2013
- Economic and Financial Crime Commission (Establishment) Act 2004
- Banks and Other Financial Institutions Act (BOFIA) 1991
- **CBN AML/CFT Regulations 2013**
- CBN Act 2017
- CBN AML/CFT Risk-Based Supervision Framework 2011

**Recent Developments (2024):**
- New guidelines for Licensing of Banks on AML/CFT/CPF (Anti-Money Laundering/Combating Financing of Terrorism/Countering Proliferation of WMD Financing)
- Prescribes minimum AML/CFT/CPF requirements for licensing new financial institutions
- Updated BDC operator guidelines (May 2024)
- Tier-1 accounts must be linked to NIN or BVN (2024 directive)

**Institutions Covered:**
- Commercial Banks
- Holding Companies (HCs)
- Merchant Banks
- Non-Interest Banks (NIBs)
- **Primary Mortgage Banks (PMBs)**
- **Microfinance Banks (MFBs)**
- **Payment Service Banks (PSBs)**
- Bureaux-de-Change (BDCs)
- Development Finance Institutions (DFIs)
- Finance Companies (FCs)
- Payment Service Providers (PSPs)

**Compliance Requirements:**
- Designation of AML chief compliance officer at management level
- Identifying AML regulations and offenses
- Understanding nature of money laundering
- Recognizing money laundering "red flags" and suspicious transactions
- Meeting reporting requirements
- Conducting customer due diligence
- Implementing risk-based approach to AML
- Maintaining record-keeping and retention policies
- Submit monthly AML reports to CBN and NFIU
- Use BVN when registering customers

**FATF Grey List Status:**
- Nigeria grey-listed in 2023
- Still on FATF Grey List as of June 2025
- Subject to increased monitoring
- Significant progress made:
  - Strengthened transparency of ultimate beneficial owners (UBOs)
  - Enhanced risk-based supervision for FIs and DNFBPs
  - NFIU improving financial intelligence usage

**Penalties for Non-Compliance:**
- License suspension/revocation/restrictions by CBN/SEC/NFIU
- Financial penalties up to hundreds of millions of naira
- Exposure to fraud and money laundering schemes
- Reputational risk

## 4. MFI SECTOR DATA (8+ Documents)

### 4.1 NUMBER OF LICENSED MICROFINANCE BANKS

**SOURCE_URL:** https://nairacompare.ng/blogs/general/top-15-microfinance-banks-in-nigeria-2024
**RETRIEVED:** 2025-12-03
**COUNTRY:** Nigeria
**CATEGORY:** Sector Data
**DOCUMENT_TYPE:** Statistics
**CERTAINTY:** High
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT:** December 2024
**CONTENT:**

**As of December 2024: 729 CBN-licensed MFBs**

**Breakdown by Tier:**
- **National MFBs:** 9 (operating nationwide)
- **State MFBs:** 121 (serving specific states)
- **Unit MFBs:** 599 (localized operations)

**Historical Context:**
- 894 companies licensed as MFBs as of February 2023
- CBN revoked **179 MFB licenses in 2023**
- Primary reasons: non-compliance, inadequate capitalization, deficient corporate governance

**Other Sources Cite:**
- Over 900 MFBs in Nigeria (some sources)
- Over 916 licensed MFBs (some sources)

**Most Authoritative Figure: 729 licensed MFBs (December 2024)** - reflects impact of CBN's regulatory cleanup and stricter enforcement.
